Russian media reported quoting President Putin had given approval to a â€˜special military operationâ€™ in the Donbas region of Ukraine.

Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s â€œspecial military operationâ€ in eastern Ukraine has been swiftly condemned by several nations.

The authorisation by Putin was made at the same time as the United Nations Security Council met late on Wednesday for its second emergency meeting this week to urge de-escalation and return to diplomatic talks.

Russian media reported quoting Putin he had given approval to the operation in the Donbas region of Ukraine, where Moscow earlier recognised rebel-held territories in Luhansk and Donetsk and said they had asked for its â€œhelpâ€.

Here is how the world is reacting:

Ukraine

Ukraineâ€™s Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba said Putin had â€œlaunched a full-scale invasion of Ukraineâ€ and that peaceful cities were â€œunder strikesâ€.

â€œThis is a war of aggression. Ukraine will defend itself and will win. The world can and must stop Putin. The time to act is now,â€ he tweeted.

Speaking at an emergency UN Security Council meeting, Ukrainian Ambassador Sergiy Kyslytsya said it was too late to talk about de-escalation. â€œI call on every one of you to do everything possible to stop the war,â€ he said.

United States

President Joe Biden has condemned Russia for an â€œunprovoked and unjustified attackâ€ on Ukraine while promising that his country and its allies â€œwill hold Russia accountableâ€.

â€œPresident Putin has chosen a premeditated war that will bring a catastrophic loss of life and human suffering. Russia alone is responsible for the death and destruction this attack will bring, and the United States and its allies and partners will respond in a united and decisive way. The world will hold Russia accountable,â€ he said.

Tomorrow, I will be meeting with the Leaders of the G7, and the United States and our Allies and partners will be imposing severe sanctions on Russia. We will continue to provide support and assistance to Ukraine and the Ukrainian people. â€” President Biden (@POTUS) February 24, 2022

G7

The Group of Seven industrialised nations strongly condemned Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine and said they would bring forward severe and coordinated economic and financial sanctions against Moscow.

â€œThis crisis is a serious threat to the rules-based international order, with ramifications well beyond Europe,â€ the G7 leaders said in a joint statement, adding Russian President Vladimir Putin had re-introduced war to the European continent.

â€œHe has put himself on the wrong side of history,â€ said the leaders in the statement released by Germany.

The leaders also said they supported consistent and constructive engagement and coordination among major energy producers and consumers towards stable global energy supplies and were ready to act to address potential disruption.

United Nations

Secretary-General Antonio Guterres condemned Russiaâ€™s actions, telling Putin to â€œbring your troops back to Russiaâ€.

â€œIn the name of humanity, do not allow a war to start in Europe which could be worst war since the beginning of the century with consequences not only devastating for Ukraine, not only tragic for the Russian Federation but with an impact cannot even foresee.â€

Speaking at the UN Security Council, Guterres implored Putin to â€œgive peace a chance.â€

World Health Organization

The UN health agency has voiced alarm over an expected health emergency in Ukraine.

â€œAmid the conflict rapidly unfolding in Ukraine, the WHO Regional Office for Europe reiterates its deepest concern for the safety, health and wellbeing of all civilians impacted by the crisis in the country and possibly beyond,â€ the office said in a statement.

United Kingdom

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he was appalled by the horrific events in Ukraine and has spoken to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to discuss the next steps.

â€œPresident Putin has chosen a path of bloodshed and destruction by launching this unprovoked attack on Ukraine,â€ Johnson tweeted.

In a televised address to the nation, he said Western powers would impose massive sanctions to hobble the Russian economy. â€œToday, in concert with our allies, we will agree a massive package of economic sanctions designed in time to hobble the Russian economy,â€ he said.

I am appalled by the horrific events in Ukraine and I have spoken to President Zelenskyy to discuss next steps. President Putin has chosen a path of bloodshed and destruction by launching this unprovoked attack on Ukraine. The UK and our allies will respond decisively. â€” Boris Johnson (@BorisJohnson) February 24, 2022

European Union

The bloc will hold Moscow accountable for the â€œunjustifiedâ€ attack on Ukraine, the chief of the EUâ€™s Executive Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said.

â€œIn these dark hours, our thoughts are with Ukraine and the innocent women, men and children as they face this unprovoked attack and fear for their lives,â€ she said on Twitter.

The EU is expected to discuss a further sanctions package on Russia at an emergency meeting later in the day.

Speaking at a news conference alongside the President of the European Council Charles Michel, von der Leyen said EU sanctions will â€œseriously degradeâ€ Russiaâ€™s economy.

NATO

The Atlantic allianceâ€™s secretary general said Russia had â€œchosen the path of aggression against a sovereign and independent country.â€

The attack â€œputs at risk countless civilian lives,â€ Jens Stoltenberg said in a statement, describing it as a â€œgrave breach of international law, and a serious threat to Euro-Atlantic security.â€

After chairing an emergency meeting of NATO ambassadors, Stoltenberg said the Western military alliance will deploy capabilities and forces on its territory after Russian invaded Ukraine, saying it put over 100 warplanes on high alert.

NATO leaders will also hold a virtual summit on Friday.

International Olympic Committee

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) said Russia had breached the Olympic Truce that is currently in effect, which aims to harness the power of sport to promote peace and dialogue.

A UN resolution calling for cooperate with the IOC and the International Paralympic Committee â€œto use sport as a tool to promote peace, dialogue and reconciliationâ€ was adopted on 2 December 2021 by consensus of all 193 UN Member States.

Belarus

President Alexander Lukashenko said the Belarusian armed forces were not taking part in Russiaâ€™s military operation against Ukraine, the Belta news agency reported.

â€œOur troops are taking no part in this operation,â€ Lukashenko was quoted as saying.

Turkey

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has denounced Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine as a â€œheavy blowâ€ to regional peace.

â€œWe reject Russiaâ€™s military operation,â€ Erdogan said in a televised speech, calling it as a â€œheavy blow to regional peace and stability.â€

Czech Republic

Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine is a â€œbarbaric act of aggressionâ€ and that his country will respond together with its allies,

â€œThe Kremlinâ€™s decision to launch a completely unprovoked attack is unacceptable and in contradiction to international law,â€ he posted on Twitter.

I strongly condemn the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The Kremlin's decision to launch a completely unprovoked attack is unacceptable and in contradiction to international law. Together with Allies, we will respond to this barbaric act of aggression. â€” Jan LipavskÃ½ (@JanLipavsky) February 24, 2022

China

China rejected calling Russiaâ€™s moves on Ukraine an â€œinvasionâ€ and urged all sides to exercise restraint.

â€œYou are using a typical Western media question method of using the word invasion,â€ Hua Chunying, spokesperson at Chinaâ€™s foreign ministry told reporters.

â€œChina is closely monitoring the latest situation. We call on all sides to exercise restraint to prevent the situation from getting out of control.â€

The Chinese embassy in Ukraine told its citizens in Ukraine to stay put at home as a precautionary measure, following the bombings of some Ukrainian cities.

Poland

Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki demanded an immediate reaction to Russiaâ€™s aggression on Ukraine, seeking the â€œfiercest possibleâ€ sanctions.

â€œWe must immediately respond to Russiaâ€™s criminal aggression on Ukraine,â€ Morawiecki tweeted.

â€œEurope and the free world have to stop Putin. Todayâ€™s European Council should approve fiercest possible sanctions. Our support for Ukraine must be real.â€

The countryâ€™s health ministry said it is preparing a medical train to transport the wounded, adding that Polish hospitals were ready to receive thousands of patients.

We must immediately respond to Russia's criminal aggression on Ukraine.

Europe and the free world has to stop Putin. Today's European Council should approve fiercest possible sanctions.

Our support for Ukraine must be real. â€” Mateusz Morawiecki (@MorawieckiM) February 24, 2022

Hungary

Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said â€œwar is the worst-case scenarioâ€.

â€œThe task now, just as always, is to guarantee the security of Hungarian people,â€ Sjijjarto posted on his official Facebook page.

â€œOur embassy in Kyiv is operating, and ready to help Hungarians who are in the Ukraine right now.â€

Bulgaria

Bulgarian President Rumen Radev said his country was preparing to evacuate by land more than 4,000 ethnic Bulgarians from Ukraine and was ready to host other Ukrainian refugees.

Bulgarian Prime Minister Kiril Petkov said the Balkan country would prepare hotels and other tourism bases to host them.

Australia

Prime Minister Scott Morrison said sanctions against Russia would become law Friday but would not take effect until the end of March.

He said the time was needed to give â€œopportunities for businesses that have had very legitimate operations and business interests in Russia and in the affected territories of Ukraine to be able to make changes to their arrangements.â€

â€œThe reason weâ€™re doing this is there must be a price for the unprovoked, unlawful, unwarranted, unjustified attacks and threats and intimidation that has been imposed by Russia on Ukraine. This cannot be a consequence-free action by Vladimir Putin and the Russian regime,â€ Morrison said.

Germany

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz condemned Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine as a â€œblatant breach of international lawâ€ that â€œcannot be justified by anythingâ€.

He said western sanctions would ensure Russia paid a â€œbitter priceâ€ for its attack on Ukraine and that Putin had made â€œa serious mistake.â€

France

President Emmanuel Macron has said France will stand by Ukraineâ€™s side and warned that Russiaâ€™s invasion of its neighbour will have durable and â€œdeepâ€ consequences for the continent of Europe.

â€œWe will respond without weakness to this act of war, with calm, determination and unity,â€ Macron said in an address to the French nation.

Spain

The Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez condemned the Russian military operation in Ukraine and said he is in contact with allies from NATO to coordinate a response.

Italy

Prime Minister Mario Draghi condemned Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine as â€œunjustified and unjustifiable.â€

â€œItaly stands by the Ukrainian people and institutions in this dramatic moment,â€ he said in a statement. â€œWe are working with our European and NATO allies to respond immediately, with unity and determination.â€

Draghi has called on Russia to â€œwithdraw unconditionallyâ€ from Ukraine and â€œput an immediate end to the bloodshed.â€

Greece

Greece slammed Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine as â€œrevisionistâ€ as it scrambled to bolster consular support for its ethnic community of over 100,000 people in the country.

â€œWe strongly condemn the Russian aggression against an independent country,â€ Greek President Katerina Sakellaropoulou said.

Deputy foreign minister Andreas Katsaniotis said that â€œwhile other countries withdrew their diplomats, we increased our personnel.â€

Finland

Finlandâ€™s President Sauli NiinistÃ¶ strongly condemned the Russian military measures, describing them as an assault not just on Ukraine, but â€œon the entire European security order.â€

â€œWe feel deep compassion towards Ukraine and are seeking ways to increase our support to Ukraine,â€ he said.

I strongly condemn the military measures Russia has started in Ukraine. Russia's acts target Ukraine, but at the same time they are an attack on the entire European security order. We feel deep compassion towards Ukraine and are seeking ways to increase our support to Ukraine. â€” Sauli NiinistÃ¶ (@niinisto) February 24, 2022

Sweden

Swedenâ€™s Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson said the defence ministry will look at ways of strengthening Ukraineâ€™s capacity to resist Russiaâ€™s invasion.

â€œI have â€¦ today given the Defence Minister Peter Hultqvist the task of immediately preparing a decision so that we, from the Swedish side, can support Ukraine with further ways toâ€¦ to strengthen their resilience,â€ Andersson told reporters during a news conference.

Canada

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in a statement called Russiaâ€™s attacks â€œunprovokedâ€ and â€œa clear further violation of Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrityâ€.

Trudeau said he would meet with partners from the Group of Seven to shape a collective response, â€œincluding by imposing sanctions additional to those announced earlier this week.â€

â€œThese reckless and dangerous acts will not go unpunished.â€

Iran

Iran urged its citizens residing in Ukraine to leave the country, Iranâ€™s semi-official ISNA news agency reported.

Iranâ€™s embassy in Ukraine is currently working on obtaining flight permits for the evacuation flights given that the Ukrainian airspace is currently closed, ISNA added.

Moldova

President Maia Sandu said Moldova would introduce a state of emergency and was ready to accept tens of thousands of people coming in from neighbouring Ukraine.

â€œWe will help people who need our help and support,â€ she said.

Slovakia

Prime Minister Eduard Heger said Slovakia condemns â€œin strongest possible termsâ€ Russiaâ€™s attack on neighbour Ukraine.

â€œTimes when democratic world wants to live in peace, Russia wants war. We are ready and will act united,â€ he said.

Qatar

In a statement, Qatarâ€™s Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani urged all parties to exercise restraint and to resolve all conflicts through â€œconstructive dialogue and diplomatic meansâ€.

â€œSheikh Tamim also called the protection of civilians and the prioritisation of the humanitarian situation,â€ the statement said.

India

The Indian embassy in Ukraine said arrangements were being made to evacuate Indians since the Ukrainian airspace had been closed.

Lithuania

President Gitanas Nauseda said the Lithuanian parliament will decide whether to declare a state of emergency.

Japan

Prime Minister Fumio Kishida condemned Russiaâ€™s military actions and said Japan will respond in a speedy fashion together with the US and other allies.

â€œThis Russian invasion stands to put at risk the basic principle of international order that forbids one-sided action of force in an attempt to change the status quo. We strongly condemn Russia, and we will respond speedily in cooperation with the US and other Western nations,â€ Kishida added.

South Korea

President Moon Jae-in said at a National Security Council meeting that Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty, territory, and independence must be respected.

South Korea will join in unspecified multilateral economic sanctions on Russia in response to its military operations in Ukraine but is not considering adopting unilateral measures.

article_text:
Since news of the Ukraine-Russia conflict broke, NATO has been a hot topic of discussion. Some member countries have called on Article 4. This ensures NATO members consult whenever any country feels their territory, security or independence is under threat. However, there remains confusion over which European countries are (and are not) in NATO, and why.

Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine in the early hours of Thursday (24 February 2022) has been justified by Russian president Vladimir Putin as a â€œdemilitarisation and denazificationâ€ to protect Russian-speaking citizens of Donetsk and Luhansk in eastern Ukraine.

As reported by the BBC, Putin also accused the US and NATO members of ignoring his requests to reject Ukraine from joining the alliance. At the 2007 Munich Security Conference, he claimed: â€œIt is obvious that NATO expansion does not have any relation with the modernisation of the alliance itself or with ensuring security in Europe. On the contrary, it represents a serious provocation that reduces the level of mutual trust.â€

Given the current state of relationships between the neighbouring countries and the fears of other former Soviet Bloc nations, people are curious to know which European countries are members of the Treaty.

NEW: The US draft IS still a thing: What it means as Biden vows to back Ukraine

The Fairly OddParents: Fairly Odder | Trailer | Paramount+ BridTV 8646 The Fairly OddParents: Fairly Odder | Trailer | Paramount+ https://i.ytimg.com/vi/yFeVZwfl0eg/hqdefault.jpg 961518 961518 center 22886

There are six EU countries not in NATO, neither is Switzerland

Austria, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Malta and Sweden are the only EU states that are not members of NATO. Switzerland â€“ which isnâ€™t a member of the EU â€“ also remains neutral regarding military conflict.

However, all the countries mentioned above, except Cyprus, are members of NATOâ€™s Partnership For Peace (PfP) programme. Established in 1994, the PfP aims to â€œâ€œncrease stability, diminish threats to peace and build strengthened security relationships between NATO and non-member countries in the Euro-Atlantic area,â€ as per the official website.

The full list of the 30 NATO members is available here. Of the 30 member countries, all are deemed in Europe apart from the US and Canada.

Despite Ukraine contributing towards NATO missions, the country is still not an official member. However, the former Soviet state has been close to securing ties in the past two years, something that has angered Russia and Putin. In September 2020, Ukraine president Volodymyr Zelenskyy approved Ukraineâ€™s National Security Strategy, with the goal to strengthen partnerships with NATO in hopes of future membership.

MORE: Hereâ€™s the meaning of â€˜full tontoâ€™, Ben Wallaceâ€™s remark on Putin

Spoke with President Sauli @niinisto on #Russia's attack on #Ukraine. At our #NATO Summit tomorrow our close partners #Finland, #Sweden & the #EU will join us to address the greatest crisis for European security in a generation. â€” Jens Stoltenberg (@jensstoltenberg) February 24, 2022

Why are Austria and Switzerland not in NATO?

Austria was granted neutrality in 1955 through the Constitutional Law On The Neutrality Of Austria, stating its â€œpermanent neutrality of its own accordâ€. Austria committed itself to â€œmaintain and defend its neutrality with all means at its disposalâ€ in exchange for the withdrawal of Allied forces (Soviet Union, US, UK and France) which had occupied the country since 1945 and the end of the Second World War.

Switzerland has remained fiercely neutral regarding military conflicts, with Alexandre Vautraver â€“ Swiss Military Reviewâ€™s editor-in-chief â€“ stating Article 5 of the NATO treaty was â€œincompatible with neutralityâ€ as it follows the principal of collective defence, implying an attack on one ally is considered an attack on all allies.

In an unprovoked attack on Ukraine, all of Europe may be on the edge of a nuclear catastrophe as Putin moves Russian troops in closer to capture the nation. On Thursday, February 24th Russian troops had moved in to capture the abandon reactor at the Chernobyl Nuclear powerplant, giving Russia the advantage of a â€œnuclear threat.â€ The result of combat between the two countries has already stirred up residual radiation, causing an extreme spike in radiation levels, which could lead to decade old residual nuclear fallout being distributed across Europe.

The nuclear reactor meltdown of 1986 caused an international incident, causing the evacuation of the city of Chernobyl. If Putin can seize the Chernobyl power plant, they will be able to use the threat of nuclear war to allow the surrender of independent territories, possibly even all of Ukraine. The Ukrainian President spoke on Twitter, announcing this was now a War on all of Europe.

Not only have Russian forces moved in to take Chernobyl, but Ukraineâ€™s capitol Kiev, and surrounding cities are also under attack seemingly from all directions. Reports from Russia show Putin has fired missiles on Kiev1, Odessa2, and Chuhuiv, destroying buildings and apartment complexes. Initial reports state eighteen were killed in Odessa, while photos emerged online of injured and bloodied Ukrainians in Chuhuiv, including those mourning their lost family and friends who perished during the attack3.

Early reports indicated that Belarusian troops had invaded alongside Russian troops, though President Alexander Lukashenko of Belarus denied these allegations.

â€œOur troops are not taking any part in this operation,â€ the Belarusian president assured4.

Russiaâ€™s Plan of Attack

Putin announced his plan of attack, which was ignored by much of the world. Following Chinaâ€™s 2022 Winter Olympic Games, Putin sent in troops to attack, targeting Chernobyl, Kyiv, Pripyat, Odessa, Crimea, and Eastern Ukraineâ€™s Separatist regions.

The Chernobyl Exclusion Zone is stated to be one of the most radioactive places which exist on Earth. According to a report5 environmental impacts still occur to this day, including fish, milk, meat, and even wood from trees.

â€œThe Chernobyl accident was the largest nuclear accident in history. The higher radionuclide depositions occurred in Belarus, Russia and Ukraine, but high deposition also occurred in a number of other European countries6.â€

â€œOf the 600 workers present on the site, 134 suffered from radiation sickness. Of those, 28 died in the first three months. Another 19 died in the 1987-2004 period of various causes, not necessarily associated with radiation exposure.â€

Under the guise of the abandoned Ukrainian cities, Putin was able to advance on Ukrainian troops undetected.

Biological Warfare

Radiation Levels

Radiation Levels have skyrocketed according to real-time radiation monitoring of Chernobyl7. On February 23rd, 2022 steady levels had been reported for years around 3,000 nSv/h, yet on February 24th, 2022 during the Russian invasion, it rose to over 65,000 nSv/h. That is an over two thousand percent [2083%] increase in radiation levels.

This data means that the Russian invasion of Ukraine has become full-scale biological warfare. Now, Ukrainian [and Russian] troops are being exposed to decade old residual radiation from the largest nuclear reactor meltdown in the history of humanity. Should other countries become involved, they will also risk exposure to gamma ray ionizing radiation.

Image Source: JMBK.NEWS

Gamma Rays

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) defines gamma rays as â€œa radiation hazard for the entire body8.â€ Gamma rays have enough penetrating power to destroy tissue, and damage DNA.

According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), Gamma rays are the most penetrating type of radiation, capable of traveling miles through air and penetrating deeply into tissue. Gamma rays are known to cause extensive damage to tissues extending deep into vital organs9.

As the Russian troops kick up gamma rays and other radioactive dust, this active biowarfare extend its impacts beyond Ukraineâ€™s borders. Fighting on terrain alongside active nuclear reactors opens potential for an inconceivable international disaster, while functioning as a strategic advantage for Putin. The frightening possibility is the sheer extent that Putinâ€™s platoon will go to conquer Ukraine, claiming their victory.

To outside countries across the world, individual leaders and their officials have spoken on behalf of Ukraine, condemning their actions, many countries citing this offensive and dangerous invasion as an act of war on all of Europe. Beyond the horrifying potential of another nuclear reactor meltdown, Putinâ€™s actions show his distaste for the rest of the world, as his troops lead their attack on a European ally. Beyond government officials, the aggressive breach of the Ukrainian borders was felt by billions of people around the world.

Ukraineâ€™s Response

The President of Ukraine [ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ñ‚ Ğ£ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ—Ğ½Ğ¸] Volodymyr Zelenskyy stated that Russian occupation forces were attempting to seize the Chernobyl power plant. Ukraineâ€™s President also alerted other nationâ€™s leaders stating this was a declaration of war against all of Europe.

Volodymyr Zelenskyy

â€œOur defenders are giving their lives so that the tragedy of 1986 will not be repeated.â€ â€œThis is a declaration of war against the whole of Europe10.â€

Our defenders are giving their lives so that the tragedy of 1986 will not be repeated. Reported this to @SwedishPM. This is a declaration of war against the whole of Europe.February 24th 202220,353 Retweets52,632 Likes

â€œWe are creating an anti-Putin coalition. I spoke with @vonderleyen, @EmmanuelMacron, @karlnehammer and @RTErdogan about concrete sanctions and concrete assistance for our military. We are waiting for decisive action11.â€

â€œA package of additional tough sanctions against Russia from the EU is approaching. Discussed all the details with @EmmanuelMacron. We demand the disconnection of Russia from SWIFT, the introduction of a no-fly zone over Ukraine and other effective steps to stop the aggressor12.â€

â€œPhone conversation with @JustinTrudeau ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ Today there is a full-scale war throughout ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦! We demand the immediate imposition of additional tough sanctions against Russia. Now, more than ever, we need concrete support! I count on leadership of ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ in this process13!â€

Global Response

European countries united together, enlisting each otherâ€™s support to fight the imperialist Russian takeover, as the battle for Ukraine wages on. Across the world, nations condemned the actions of Putin, and the advancement of his troops on a non-hostile military force. Despite the blood on the front lines, a sense of unity has been provoked throughout the world, where many countries publicly oppose authoritarian imperialism, despite having ties to the regimes themselves.

These restrictions that are made to harm the tyrannical Putin, will ultimately be more devastating to the people under Putinâ€™s rule. Russian citizens will suffer as a result of the Russian invasion through the increased cost of international products, through sanctions covering every possible sector.

France

Emmanuel Macron called Putinâ€™s offensive maneuver a â€œrefusalâ€ of diplomacy, calling for European unity against the â€œghosts of the past.â€

Emmanuel Macron

â€œâ€By denying his word, by refusing the diplomatic route, by choosing war, President Putin has not only attacked Ukraine. It has decided to strike the most serious attack on peace and stability in our Europe14.â€â€

â€œâ€In these troubled hours when the ghosts of the past are reborn, when manipulations will be numerous, let us not give up anything of our unity15.â€â€

Germany

Germany spoke on behalf of the international community calling this as a â€œday of shame.â€ Vowing to respond alongside other European nations in solidarity to Ukraine.

AuÃŸenministerin Annalena Baerbock

â€œâ€By attacking the â€â€#Ukraineâ€â€, #Russlandâ€â€ is breaking â€â€ with the most elementary rules of the international order. The international community will not forget Russia this day of shame. We will respond together with our partners. All our solidarity goes to Ukraine16.â€â€

Germanyâ€™s Foreign Office

â€œâ€In the â€â€#Ukraineâ€â€, combat operations & missile attacks take place. German citizens are urged to leave the country. If you cannot leave the country in a safe way, stay in a protected place for the time being17.â€

â€œToday we are waking up in a different #Europe, in a different world. With the military attack on #Ukraine, the Russian government is breaking the most fundamental rules of the international order, right in front of the eyes of the world. â€“ Foreign Minister @ABaerbockâ€

G7 Germany

â€œWe strongly condemn Russiaâ€™s military attack on Ukraine. It is a serious breach of international law. The #G7 are determined to maintain peace and stability18. Declaration: https://www.g7germany.de/g7-enâ€

Switzerland

The Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs cited numerous arrests of peaceful protesters, and media restrictions on Russian journalists, demanding the right to free speech and the right to assemble. Speaking for Switzerland, the Department condemned the attacks, stating concerns for Ukrainian civilians.

Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs

â€œSwitzerland condemns the Russian invasion of Ukraine in the strongest terms. We urge Russia to immediately cease military aggression and withdraw its troops from Ukrainian territory. This is a gross violation of international law. International humanitarian law must be respected. We are very concerned about the danger to innocent civilians.19â€

â€œSwitzerland is concerned about reports of numerous arrests of peaceful protestors in relation with Russiaâ€™s military intervention in Ukraine and calls on the Russian Federation to ensure the right to freedom of assembly. We further share the concerns of the OSCE Media Freedom Representative regarding serious restrictions on Russian media reporting on the armed conflict. The freedom of media needs to be equally respected20.â€

Sweden

Swedish Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson21 announced the country stood in solidarity with Ukraine. PM Andersson showed her support voicing strong condemnation of Russiaâ€™s invasion. The Swedish Prime Minister also cited the need for what she referred to as â€œmassive EU sanctionsâ€ on Russia.

Magdalena Andersson

â€œSpoke to Ukrainian President @ZelenskyyUa to express full solidarity with Ukraine and strong condemnation of Russiaâ€™s invasion and flagrant violation of international law. We agreed on need for massive EU sanctions on Russia and increased support for Ukraine in this dark hour22.â€

â€œI spoke this morning with President @niinisto in Finland and Prime Minister @jonasgahrstore in Norway. Reassuring Nordic and European unity and determination in solidarity with the Ukraine23.â€

Finland

Finlandâ€™s President Sauli NiinistÃ¶ also responded with his committed Nordic Unity, condemning Russiaâ€™s invasion. NiinistÃ¶ vowed to increase support to Ukraine, at all costs. President NiinistÃ¶ also allocated fifty-million dollars contribution to Ukraine in an effort to fight back against Russia. The Ukrainian President publicly acknowledged his generous contribution via Twitter, thanking him for his support.

Sauli NiinistÃ¶

â€œI spoke on the phone with @SwedishPM Andersson and Norwegian PM @jonasgahrstore this morning. A shared view of the dangerous situation, a strong commitment to Nordic unity24.â€

â€œI strongly condemn the military measures Russia has started in Ukraine. Russiaâ€™s acts target Ukraine, but at the same time they are an attack on the entire European security order. We feel deep compassion towards Ukraine and are seeking ways to increase our support to Ukraine25.â€

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy gave thanks to Sauli NiinistÃ¶ for his contribution of fifty-million dollars to their war efforts.

Volodymyr Zelenskyy

â€œDiscussed with @niinisto countering the aggressor. Informed about our defense, insidious shelling of Kyiv. Grateful to ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡® for allocating $50 million aid. Itâ€™s an effective contribution to the anti-war coalition. We keep working. We need to increase sanctions & ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ defense support26â€

Norway

Norwayâ€™s Prime Minister stated the attack weas a serious violation of international law, and put the lives of innocent people at risk. Norway, he stated stood with Europe during what Jonas Gahr StÃ¸re referred to as â€œthe most serious time in Europeâ€™s history.â€

Jonas Gahr StÃ¸re â€“ Prime minister

@jonasgahrstore â€œâ€Today I have met with good allies in Northern Europe â€“ the Baltics, the UK, the Netherlands and the Nordic countries. Now ready for a NATO summit. It is important to show unity and strength in the security policy crisis we are in27.â€â€

â€â€œNorway condemns Russiaâ€™s military attacks on Ukraine. The attack is a serious violation of international law and puts the lives of innocent people at risk. Norway stands with allies and Europeans at this most serious moment in Europeâ€™s history28.â€â€

Lithuania
